lines.text: Cornets. Enter CORIOLANUS, MENENIUS, all the Gentry, COMINIUS, TITUS LARTIUS, and other Senators

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: Tullus Aufidius then had made new head?

lines.speaker: lartius
lines.text: He had, my lord; and that it was which caused Our swifter composition.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: So then the Volsces stand but as at first, Ready, when time shall prompt them, to make road. Upon's again.

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: They are worn, lord consul, so, That we shall hardly in our ages see Their banners wave again.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: Saw you Aufidius?

lines.speaker: lartius
lines.text: On safe-guard he  came to me; and did curse Against the Volsces, for they had so vilely Yielded the town: he is retired to Antium.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: Spoke he of me?

lines.speaker: lartius
lines.text: He did, my lord.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: How? what?

lines.speaker: lartius
lines.text: How often he had met you, sword to sword; That of all things upon the earth he hated Your person most, that he would pawn his fortunes To hopeless restitution, so he might Be call'd your vanquisher.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: At Antium lives he?

lines.speaker: lartius
lines.text: At Antium.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: I wish I had a cause to seek him there, To oppose his hatred fully. Welcome home. Behold, these are the tribunes of the people, The tongues o' the common mouth: I do despise them; For they do prank them in authority, Against all noble sufferance.
Enter SICINIUS and BRUTUS

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Pass no further.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: Ha! what is that?

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: It will be dangerous to go on: no further.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: What makes this change?

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: The matter?

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: Hath he not pass'd the noble and the common?

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Cominius, no.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: Have I had children's voices?

lines.speaker: first senator
lines.text: Tribunes, give way; he shall to the market-place.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: The people are incensed against him.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Stop, Or all will fall in broil.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: Are these your herd? Must these have voices, that can yield them now And straight disclaim their tongues? What are your offices? You being their mouths, why rule you not their teeth? Have you not set them on?

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Be calm, be calm.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: It is a purposed thing, and grows by plot, To curb the will of the nobility: Suffer't, and live with such as cannot rule Nor ever will be ruled.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Call't not a plot: The people cry you mock'd them, and of late, When corn was given them gratis, you repined; Scandal'd the suppliants for the people, call'd them Time-pleasers, flatterers, foes to nobleness.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: Why, this was known before.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Not to them all.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: Have you inform'd them sithence?

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: How! I inform them!

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: You are like to do such business.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Not unlike, Each way, to better yours.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: Why then should I be consul? By yond clouds, Let me deserve so ill as you, and make me Your fellow tribune.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: You show too much of that For which the people stir: if you will pass To where you are bound, you must inquire your way, Which you are out of, with a gentler spirit, Or never be so noble as a consul, Nor yoke with him for tribune.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Let's be calm.

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: The people are abused; set on. This paltering Becomes not Rome, nor has Coriolanus Deserved this so dishonour'd rub, laid falsely I' the plain way of his merit.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: Tell me of corn! This was my speech, and I will speak't again--

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Not now, not now.

lines.speaker: first senator
lines.text: Not in this heat, sir, now.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: Now, as I live, I will. My nobler friends, I crave their pardons: For the mutable, rank-scented many, let them Regard me as I do not flatter, and Therein behold themselves: I say again, In soothing them, we nourish 'gainst our senate The cockle of rebellion, insolence, sedition, Which we ourselves have plough'd for, sow'd, and scatter'd, By mingling them with us, the honour'd number, Who lack not virtue, no, nor power, but that Which they have given to beggars.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Well, no more.

lines.speaker: first senator
lines.text: No more words, we beseech you.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: How! no more! As for my country I have shed my blood, Not fearing outward force, so shall my lungs Coin words till their decay against those measles, Which we disdain should tatter us, yet sought The very way to catch them.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: You speak o' the people, As if you were a god to punish, not A man of their infirmity.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: 'Twere well We let the people know't.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: What, what? his choler?

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: Choler! Were I as patient as the midnight sleep, By Jove, 'twould be my mind!

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: It is a mind That shall remain a poison where it is, Not poison any further.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: Shall remain! Hear you this Triton of the minnows? mark you His absolute 'shall'?

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: 'Twas from the canon.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: 'Shall'! O good but most unwise patricians! why, You grave but reckless senators, have you thus Given Hydra here to choose an officer, That with his peremptory 'shall,' being but The horn and noise o' the monster's, wants not spirit To say he'll turn your current in a ditch, And make your channel his? If he have power Then vail your ignorance; if none, awake Your dangerous lenity. If you are learn'd, Be not as common fools; if you are not, Let them have cushions by you. You are plebeians, If they be senators: and they are no less, When, both your voices blended, the great'st taste Most palates theirs. They choose their magistrate, And such a one as he, who puts his 'shall,' His popular 'shall' against a graver bench Than ever frown in Greece. By Jove himself! It makes the consuls base: and my soul aches To know, when two authorities are up, Neither supreme, how soon confusion May enter 'twixt the gap of both and take The one by the other.

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: Well, on to the market-place.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: Whoever gave that counsel, to give forth The corn o' the storehouse gratis, as 'twas used Sometime in Greece,--

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Well, well, no more of that.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: Though there the people had more absolute power, I say, they nourish'd disobedience, fed The ruin of the state.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Why, shall the people give One that speaks thus their voice?

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: I'll give my reasons, More worthier than their voices. They know the corn Was not our recompense, resting well assured That ne'er did service for't: being press'd to the war, Even when the navel of the state was touch'd, They would not thread the gates. This kind of service Did not deserve corn gratis. Being i' the war Their mutinies and revolts, wherein they show'd Most valour, spoke not for them: the accusation Which they have often made against the senate, All cause unborn, could never be the motive Of our so frank donation. Well, what then? How shall this bisson multitude digest The senate's courtesy? Let deeds express What's like to be their words: 'we did request it; We are the greater poll, and in true fear They gave us our demands.' Thus we debase The nature of our seats and make the rabble Call our cares fears; which will in time Break ope the locks o' the senate and bring in The crows to peck the eagles.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Come, enough.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Enough, with over-measure.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: No, take more: What may be sworn by, both divine and human, Seal what I end withal! This double worship, Where one part does disdain with cause, the other Insult without all reason, where gentry, title, wisdom, Cannot conclude but by the yea and no Of general ignorance,--it must omit Real necessities, and give way the while To unstable slightness: purpose so barr'd, it follows, Nothing is done to purpose. Therefore, beseech you,-- You that will be less fearful than discreet, That love the fundamental part of state More than you doubt the change on't, that prefer A noble life before a long, and wish To jump a body with a dangerous physic That's sure of death without it, at once pluck out The multitudinous tongue; let them not lick The sweet which is their poison: your dishonour Mangles true judgment and bereaves the state Of that integrity which should become't, Not having the power to do the good it would, For the in which doth control't.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Has said enough.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Has spoken like a traitor, and shall answer As traitors do.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: Thou wretch, despite o'erwhelm thee! What should the people do with these bald tribunes? On whom depending, their obedience fails To the greater bench: in a rebellion, When what's not meet, but what must be, was law, Then were they chosen: in a better hour, Let what is meet be said it must be meet, And throw their power i' the dust.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Manifest treason!

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: This a consul? no.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: The aediles, ho! Let him be apprehended.
Enter an AEdile

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Go, call the people: in whose name myself Attach thee as a traitorous innovator, A foe to the public weal: obey, I charge thee, And follow to thine answer.
Exit AEdile

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: Hence, old goat! Senators,  and C We'll surety him.

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: Aged sir, hands off.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: Hence, rotten thing! or I shall shake thy bones Out of thy garments.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Help, ye citizens! Enter a rabble of Citizens (Plebeians), with the AEdiles

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: On both sides more respect.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Here's he that would take from you all your power.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Seize him, AEdiles!

lines.speaker: citizens
lines.text: Down with him! down with him! Senators,  and C Weapons, weapons, weapons! 'Tribunes!' 'Patricians!' 'Citizens!' 'What, ho!' 'Sicinius!' 'Brutus!' 'Coriolanus!' 'Citizens!' 'Peace, peace, peace!' 'Stay, hold, peace!'
They all bustle about CORIOLANUS, crying

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: What is about to be? I am out of breath; Confusion's near; I cannot speak. You, tribunes To the people! Coriolanus, patience! Speak, good Sicinius.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Hear me, people; peace!

lines.speaker: citizens
lines.text: Let's hear our tribune: peace Speak, speak, speak.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: You are at point to lose your liberties: Marcius would have all from you; Marcius, Whom late you have named for consul.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Fie, fie, fie! This is the way to kindle, not to quench.

lines.speaker: first senator
lines.text: To unbuild the city and to lay all flat.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: What is the city but the people?

lines.speaker: citizens
lines.text: True, The people are the city.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: By the consent of all, we were establish'd The people's magistrates.

lines.speaker: citizens
lines.text: You so remain.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: And so are like to do.

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: That is the way to lay the city flat; To bring the roof to the foundation, And bury all, which yet distinctly ranges, In heaps and piles of ruin.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: This deserves death.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Or let us stand to our authority, Or let us lose it. We do here pronounce, Upon the part o' the people, in whose power We were elected theirs, Marcius is worthy Of present death.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Therefore lay hold of him; Bear him to the rock Tarpeian, and from thence Into destruction cast him.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: AEdiles, seize him!

lines.speaker: citizens
lines.text: Yield, Marcius, yield!

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Hear me one word; Beseech you, tribunes, hear me but a word.

lines.speaker: aedile
lines.text: Peace, peace!

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: [To BRUTUS]  Be that you seem, truly your country's friend, And temperately proceed to what you would Thus violently redress.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Sir, those cold ways, That seem like prudent helps, are very poisonous Where the disease is violent. Lay hands upon him, And bear him to the rock.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: No, I'll die here. There's some among you have beheld me fighting: Come, try upon yourselves what you have seen me.
Drawing his sword

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Down with that sword! Tribunes, withdraw awhile.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Lay hands upon him.

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: Help Marcius, help, You that be noble; help him, young and old!

lines.speaker: citizens
lines.text: Down with him, down with him!
In this mutiny, the Tribunes, the AEdiles, and the People, are beat in

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Go, get you to your house; be gone, away! All will be naught else.

lines.speaker: second senator
lines.text: Get you gone.

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: Stand fast; We have as many friends as enemies.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Sham it be put to that?

lines.speaker: first senator
lines.text: The gods forbid! I prithee, noble friend, home to thy house; Leave us to cure this cause.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: For 'tis a sore upon us, You cannot tent yourself: be gone, beseech you.

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: Come, sir, along with us.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: I would they were barbarians--as they are, Though in Rome litter'd--not Romans--as they are not, Though calved i' the porch o' the Capitol--

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Be gone; Put not your worthy rage into your tongue; One time will owe another.

lines.speaker: coriolanus
lines.text: On fair ground I could beat forty of them.

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: I could myself Take up a brace o' the best of them; yea, the two tribunes: But now 'tis odds beyond arithmetic; And manhood is call'd foolery, when it stands Against a falling fabric. Will you hence, Before the tag return? whose rage doth rend Like interrupted waters and o'erbear What they are used to bear.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Pray you, be gone: I'll try whether my old wit be in request With those that have but little: this must be patch'd With cloth of any colour.

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: Nay, come away.
Exeunt CORIOLANUS, COMINIUS, and others

lines.speaker: a patrician
lines.text: This man has marr'd his fortune.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: His nature is too noble for the world: He would not flatter Neptune for his trident, Or Jove for's power to thunder. His heart's his mouth: What his breast forges, that his tongue must vent; And, being angry, does forget that ever He heard the name of death. Here's goodly work!
A noise within

lines.speaker: second patrician
lines.text: I would they were abed!

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: I would they were in Tiber! What the vengeance! Could he not speak 'em fair?
Re-enter BRUTUS and SICINIUS, with the rabble

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Where is this viper That would depopulate the city and Be every man himself?

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: You worthy tribunes,--

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: He shall be thrown down the Tarpeian rock With rigorous hands: he hath resisted law, And therefore law shall scorn him further trial Than the severity of the public power Which he so sets at nought.

lines.speaker: first citizen
lines.text: He shall well know The noble tribunes are the people's mouths, And we their hands.

lines.speaker: citizens
lines.text: He shall, sure on't.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Sir, sir,--

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Peace!

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Do not cry havoc, where you should but hunt With modest warrant.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Sir, how comes't that you Have holp to make this rescue?

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Hear me speak: As I do know the consul's worthiness, So can I name his faults,--

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Consul! what consul?

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: The consul Coriolanus.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: He consul!

lines.speaker: citizens
lines.text: No, no, no, no, no.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: If, by the tribunes' leave, and yours, good people, I may be heard, I would crave a word or two; The which shall turn you to no further harm Than so much loss of time.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Speak briefly then; For we are peremptory to dispatch This viperous traitor: to eject him hence Were but one danger, and to keep him here Our certain death: therefore it is decreed He dies to-night.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Now the good gods forbid That our renowned Rome, whose gratitude Towards her deserved children is enroll'd In Jove's own book, like an unnatural dam Should now eat up her own!

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: He's a disease that must be cut away.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: O, he's a limb that has but a disease; Mortal, to cut it off; to cure it, easy. What has he done to Rome that's worthy death? Killing our enemies, the blood he hath lost-- Which, I dare vouch, is more than that he hath, By many an ounce--he dropp'd it for his country; And what is left, to lose it by his country, Were to us all, that do't and suffer it, A brand to the end o' the world.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: This is clean kam.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Merely awry: when he did love his country, It honour'd him.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: The service of the foot Being once gangrened, is not then respected For what before it was.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: We'll hear no more. Pursue him to his house, and pluck him thence: Lest his infection, being of catching nature, Spread further.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: One word more, one word. This tiger-footed rage, when it shall find The harm of unscann'd swiftness, will too late Tie leaden pounds to's heels. Proceed by process; Lest parties, as he is beloved, break out, And sack great Rome with Romans.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: If it were so,--

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: What do ye talk? Have we not had a taste of his obedience? Our aediles smote? ourselves resisted? Come.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Consider this: he has been bred i' the wars Since he could draw a sword, and is ill school'd In bolted language; meal and bran together He throws without distinction. Give me leave, I'll go to him, and undertake to bring him Where he shall answer, by a lawful form, In peace, to his utmost peril.

lines.speaker: first senator
lines.text: Noble tribunes, It is the humane way: the other course Will prove too bloody, and the end of it Unknown to the beginning.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Noble Menenius, Be you then as the people's officer. Masters, lay down your weapons.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Go not home.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Meet on the market-place. We'll attend you there: Where, if you bring not Marcius, we'll proceed In our first way.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: I'll bring him to you. Let me desire your company: he must come, Or what is worst will follow.
To the Senators

lines.speaker: first senator
lines.text: Pray you, let's to him.
Exeunt
